children.value: . The main purpose of this article is to help readers understand the Greyhound polynomial commitment method, how evaluation proofs work, and how to use Greyhound to prove the evaluation of a polynomial over

children.value: Next, we introduce the definition of the SIS problem and Ajtai commitment.
The SIS problem is defined as follows: given a public matrix

children.value: Regarding the Ajtai commitment, three points can be further discussed: 1. Security of the commitment, 2. Norm of the commitment message, and 3. Compressibility of the commitment value.
The binding property of the commitment is based on the SIS problem. If a malicious attacker wants to change the commitment value

children.html: t\mathbf{t}t
t=Am′\mathbf{t} = \mathbf{Am}'t=Am′

children.value: , it’s equivalent to finding a solution to the SIS problem

children.html: m−m′\mathbf{m-m'}m−m′
0=A(m−m)′,∣m−m′∣∞≤2\mathbf{0} = \mathbf{A(m-m)'}, |\mathbf{m-m}'|_\infty \leq 20=A(m−m)′,∣m−m′∣∞​≤2

children.value: Note that we can find a solution to the SIS problem satisfying

children.html: ∣m−m′∣∞≤2|\mathbf{m-m}'|_\infty \leq 2∣m−m′∣∞​≤2

children.value: because we’ve required the committed messages to be binary. This requirement that messages be binary is actually constraining the norm of

children.html: m\mathbf{m}m

children.value: to be small. In other cases, it could be that the norm of

∣m−m′∣∞≤2B|\mathbf{m-m}'|_\infty \leq 2B∣m−m′∣∞​≤2B

children.value: The proof of polynomial evaluation includes two points: 1. The polynomial commitment is correctly computed; 2. The polynomial evaluation operation is correct.
First, a prover needs to commit to polynomial

children.html: fff

children.value: according to the method in section 1.1. Then proving the correctness of the commitment computation means proving:

children.html: si=Gm−1(fi),ti=Gnt^i=Asi,u=B[t^1⋮t^r].\begin{align*} \mathbf{s}_i &= \mathbf{G}^{-1}_m(\mathbf{f}_i), \\ \mathbf{t}_i &= \mathbf{G}_n\hat{\mathbf{t}}_i = \mathbf{As}_i, \\ \mathbf{u} &= \mathbf{B}\begin{bmatrix} \hat{\mathbf{t}}_1 \\ \vdots \\ \hat{\mathbf{t}}_r \end{bmatrix}. \end{align*}si​ti​u​=Gm−1​(fi​),=Gn​t^i​=Asi​,=B⎣⎡​t^1​⋮t^r​​⎦⎤​.​
G\mathbf{G}G

children.value: Greyhound’s approach to proving the above four equations is to have the prover compute parts directly related to polynomial

children.html: fi\mathbf{f}_ifi​

children.value: , and the verifier compute the remaining parts. We’ll first show the proof process and then discuss this approach.
Assume the public parameters of the protocol are commitment keys

children.value: The third equation verifies the correctness of the inner commitment of the PCS:

\begin{align*} \mathbf{Az} & = \mathbf{A s}_1 c_1 + ... + \mathbf{A s}_r c_r\\ &= c_1\mathbf{G}_n \hat{\mathbf{t}}_1 + \cdots + c_r \mathbf{G}_n \hat{\mathbf{t}}_r. \\
\end{align*}
children.html: Az=As1c1+...+Asrcr=c1Gnt^1+⋯+crGnt^r.\begin{align*} \mathbf{Az} & = \mathbf{A s}_1 c_1 + ... + \mathbf{A s}_r c_r\\ &= c_1\mathbf{G}_n \hat{\mathbf{t}}_1 + \cdots + c_r \mathbf{G}_n \hat{\mathbf{t}}_r. \\ \end{align*}Az​=As1​c1​+...+Asr​cr​=c1​Gn​t^1​+⋯+cr​Gn​t^r​.​

children.value: The fourth equation verifies the outer commitment of the PCS.

This proof can be further optimized using Labrador’s recursive proof to reduce the proof size by rewriting the equations in (1) into the standard form of Labrador proof. For specific details, please refer to the Greyhound documentation.

children.label: 5. Using \mathcal{R}_q to Prove Polynomial Evaluation over \mathbb{F}_q

children.value: In the previous introduction, we ignored an important issue: all operations and proofs are performed over

children.html: Rq\mathcal{R}_qRq​

children.value: , while most practical applications use polynomials over

children.html: Fq\mathbb{F}_qFq​

children.value: . This section discusses how to equivalently represent polynomials over

children.html: Fq\mathbb{F}_qFq​
Rq\mathcal{R}_qRq​

children.value: , thereby using the proof methods from the previous sections.
